title: EMS Care Teams In Disaster Response -- Introduction
content: Team-based care is an essential part of the medical response to a disaster. Numerous human-made and natural disasters highlight the need for an organized system-wide approach to disaster medical care. Outside assistance is often needed as the scope of a disaster progresses beyond local capabilities. Many disaster response systems worldwide are organized to provide scalable local, regional, and national response levels. These disaster response systems are often organized into teams of disaster workers. Disaster teams vary by country and in terms of their objectives and specialization. An initial disaster response typically includes local or regional emergency medical service personnel or local medical assistance teams. Specialized teams may include surgical response teams, search and rescue teams, or mortuary assistance teams. Clinicians should understand the response levels available in their community and the command structure that helps guide this response. [1] [2] [3] [4]

title: EMS Care Teams In Disaster Response -- Issues of Concern -- Local Response
content: In the United States (US) and Europe, the local responders are the foundation of initial disaster response. Bystanders or community members at the incident scene may act as immediate responders, providing initial lifesaving care such as bleeding control. Emergency medical service (EMS) first responders, including emergency medical technicians (EMTs) and paramedics, typically make up the initial formal medical response. Local authorities manage the incident and request additional assistance as needed. Locally organized disaster teams in the US include the Medical Reserve Corps (MRC) and Community Emergency Response Teams (CERTs). There are currently hundreds of MRC teams throughout the US, typically comprised of retired and active nurses, nursing assistants, EMTs, paramedics, pharmacists, physicians, and public health workers. CERT members may have various medical and nonmedical backgrounds. These volunteer teams provide training to members and can be activated to assist with many roles during a disaster response, including medical care, mass vaccinations, first aid at large events, medical monitoring at disaster shelters, and various nonmedical tasks. [5] [6] [7] [8]

title: EMS Care Teams In Disaster Response -- Issues of Concern -- State and Regional Response
content: When a disaster overwhelms the local capabilities, the next level of response is typically organized at the state or regional level. In the US, all 50 states have emergency management agencies that assist with planning, training, and coordination of local and state-level agencies. In both the US and Europe, details of the response structure vary by state or region. Still, the response is generally coordinated through a regional and state operations center or agency. State emergency management agencies in the US organize the state's response teams. These teams may include the National Guard, EMS districts, public health, and nongovernmental organizations such as the Red Cross. Some states have State Medical Assistance Teams (SMATs), which can respond to disaster situations. The capabilities and structure of the SMATs can vary by state; however, they are often comprised of volunteers and have the ability to rapidly respond to a disaster situation to assist with medical care. [9] [10]

title: EMS Care Teams In Disaster Response -- Issues of Concern -- Federal Response
content: Large-scale or regional disasters that overwhelm local and state capabilities typically involve a federal response at the request of state-level authorities. In the US, the state governors request a national disaster declaration, which must be approved at the presidential level. When declared a national disaster, many medical resources from the federal government become available. The National Response Framework (NRF) organizes public health and medical services under Emergency Support Function No. 8 (ESF-8), which is part of the overall disaster response framework for the federal government. The National Disaster Medical System (NDMS) is a federal resource organized under the US Department of Health and Human Services (US-DHHS). The NDMS coordinates several disaster response teams, including Disaster Medical Assistance Teams (DMAT), Disaster Mortuary Assistance Teams (DMORT), National Veterinary Response Teams (NVRT), and Trauma or Critical Care response teams. DMATs deploy to a disaster area within days of a disaster and can set up a freestanding medical treatment area. A 35-member DMAT team consists of physicians, physician assistants, nurses, pharmacists, paramedics, EMTs, and no-medical logistics and communications personnel. DMAT members are considered intermittent federal employees when deployed. The DMAT brings various medical and non-medical staff members, shelter, supplies, and medications, making it fully self-sustaining for 3 days.

title: EMS Care Teams In Disaster Response -- Issues of Concern -- Federal Response
content: Outside the US, similar concepts are used. In Japan, smaller DMAT teams of 5 to 6 personnel deploy and remain self-sufficient for up to 3 days. In Israel, there is cooperation and integration between military and civilian reservists. In Turkey, 5-person National Medical Rescue Teams (NMRT) provide specialized care based on local risks. The federal-level response and resources vary from country to country but generally are reserved for larger-scale disasters.

title: EMS Care Teams In Disaster Response -- Issues of Concern -- Nongovernmental Organizations
content: Nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) comprise many of the response and recovery workforce after a disaster. The assistance of NGOs is vital. Although the management responsibility of a disaster resides with governmental officials, NGOs often work under this framework to provide essential health, shelter, and recovery functions. NGOs are typically independent of the government, consisting mostly of volunteer members, and do not exist to make a profit from their activities. Well-known NGOs include the International Federation of Red Cross (IFRC) and Red Crescent Societies, the American Red Cross, and Medecins Sans Frontieres/Doctors Without Borders.

title: EMS Care Teams In Disaster Response -- Clinical Significance
content: Disaster care teams assist from the initial response through the final recovery phase of a disaster. The initial response, often local EMS or community members, can typically occur within minutes. The state or regional level of response may take hours. Federal response with DMAT teams can take days. Each level of response in the US, from local to federal, is guided by an overlying structure called the incident command system (ICS). The ICS integrates emergency management under several functional areas: command, operations, logistics, planning, and finance and administration. It is important to understand the idea of ICS and how ICS relates to the management of disaster care teams. Clinicians practicing in a disaster area must be aware of the different response levels and the chain of command established by the ICS, which helps guide disaster response. Additionally, clinicians and responders in a disaster area must have the ability to be flexible and expect to work in less-than-ideal conditions. By understanding the types of disaster care teams available and the idea of ICS, clinicians can be better prepared to respond to a disaster in their hospital or community.
